comments.text:
+rewboss
Of course, it is hard to generalize because local conditions are different. 
I just compared 2 ICE trains from Munich to Nürnberg using the same way via 
Ingolstadt - one stops there, one doesn't. The difference is 7 minutes (ok, 
this is more than 5).
This is because train has to slow down crossing the station there (to 160 
km/h at top).
The ICE can do 0 to 160 km/h in less than 2 minutes (which is not utilized 
in order to save energy and wear); can't find values about how long it 
takes to reach  speed.
Smaller stations where ICE normally don't stop have separate tracks with no 
platforms - there the train can pass at full speed. Stopping at such a 
station would in fact cost ~ 20 minutes.
I know the difference between average and maximal speed - may be I have 
expressed some points poorly. Still, on old tracks, heavy ICE trains are 
slower than some commuter trains because of speed limits which differ by 
load per axle ratings.
And yes, you are right - the travel time difference between the train 
categories result from waiting time at connections and a lot of stops (the 
'red' category includes trains with more and less stops at same routes - it 
is a good idea to study time-tables en detail) *but* as a tourist with no 
hurry, one can save a lot of money.
comments.author: akronymus

comments.text:
+akronymus
It slows it down much more than by 5 minutes. You're just counting the time 
the train is at an actual standstill, but it actually takes quite a long 
time for it to slow down and, after the stop, accelerate again (on one 
recent journey, my train was forced to stop for three minutes to allow 
another train to pass, and that added ten minutes to the total travelling 
time). You're also confusing "cruising speed" with "average speed" -- a 
cruising speed of 200 km/h would result in an 800 km journey taking 4 hours 
if, and only if, the train never stopped on the way and never slowed. The 
cruising speed is generally the fastest speed the train travels at: the 
average speed is always noticeably less.

And saying that there are stretches where commuter trains can actually go 
faster than ICEs still doesn't mean taking a commuter train is a faster way 
to get from one place to another. As I said, from Hamburg to Munich it 
takes almost twice as long by RE/RB. Commuter trains make more stops, don't 
use the high-speed lines that do exist, are more likely to have to wait for 
other trains, and on longer journeys you have to change trains more often, 
sometimes waiting up to an hour for a connection.
comments.author: rewboss

comments.text:
+rewboss
No, this isn't quite true. Every stop slows down travel time for about five 
minutes on a high-speed connection.
There are three categories of tracks:
- the very high-speed ones (with concrete base between rails), where 300++ 
km/h is possible, but these are rare (you see the speed display for ten, 
fifteen minutes - this doesn't influence overall traveling time very much, 
if your math teacher has done a bit of good work)
- old high-speed-tracks, where former IC trains could travel at 200 km/h, 
but the new and very heavy ICE are slowed down there to 160 at most
- ordinary tracks, on which light trains can do between 120 and 160 km/h, 
but heavy ICE only 120 km/h (which means, cheap red trains are often faster 
there - I measured it myself for a company who needed the data)

The average speed of 130 km/h is the one for the mentioned relation between 
Hamburg and Munich (try to do the math, and if you can't, punch this 
teacher until you hit him really bad). A cruising speed of 200-250 would 
result in 3-4 hours travel time with some stops.
comments.author: akronymus

comments.text:
+akronymus
It takes 11 or 12 hours to get from Hamburg to Munich using only RB and RE 
trains, with 5 or 6 changes. For example, leaving Hamburg at 11:54, you 
have to change in Uelzen, Halle, Naumburg, Jena, Nuremberg and Ingolstadt, 
to arrive in Munich at 23:40. That's about the fastest connection I can 
find. What you save in train fares you have to spend on an additional night 
in a hotel.

When calculating the "average speed" of a train, you have to remember that 
the train does stop several times en route. In my experience, 130 km/h 
isn't the average cruising speed of an ICE, but the slowest. Cruising 
speeds of 200 to 250 are far more usual.
comments.author: rewboss

comments.text:
+TJ Wilson
Except, TJ, Europeans also travel those distances. Just not within one 
country. And the reason it would take you two days from Chicago to LA by 
train is that the US train system is archaic. The train connection between 
Chicago and LA takes longer than driving by car, counting only net travel 
time, not time for sleepovers etc. Guess what - on long distances in 
Europe, a car has a snowball's chance in hell to compete with the train. 
Because even with the autobahn having in some places no speed limit, you're 
not going to do 300 kph. I once posted jokingly on Facebook on a day when I 
had a nice company BMW "Traveled 210 kph on the autobahn and still someone 
passed me on the right" (which actually would be forbidden in Germany and 
is generally seen as rude behavior by speed addicts) - the point, though, 
was that the autobahn was directly next to the ICE tracks and the train was 
passing me with what must have been 250 kph+.

You can take trains traveling at that speed, though with changing trains, 
from Amsterdam all the way down to Malaga and Seville, and tolerating a few 
stretches with lower speed, you can even start in Hamburg, and the system 
is being expanded, with express tracks in Scandinavia, for example. But of 
course over these distances, people would not take the train but fly. Which 
is why Chicago to LA is a rather silly example. You see, your notion that 
Europeans have no idea about geographic distances couldn't be further from 
the truth. I've even lived in Texas. The state would be a dream to 
construct a high speed rail line in, because the areas with the largest 
population are flat as a pancake and the spaces in between are wide open. A 
triangular line Dallas-Houston-San Antonio-Austin-Forth Worth-Dallas 
following I45, I10 and I35 would be a piece of cake. And precisely because 
the distances are so large, high speed trains could truly use their speed 
as opposed to Germany, where they reach the next major city after 30-45 
minutes  and have to stop again. Disregarding traffic, the trip from Dallas 
to Houston by car takes over 3h according to Google Maps. A high speed 
train could make it in a bit over 1h, city center to city center. That's 
tough to beat even for planes. The flight takes 55 minutes.

No, the problem in the US is NOT distances. Quite the contrary, the 
distances are far better for high speed trains.

+Oliver H

It is indeed perspective, but also a matter of distance.  In my part of the 
USA, there are usually  only one or two trains a day between my major 
university town and the nearest big city, Chicago.  There is no train 
service at all to the next larger city, St. Louis.  A train delay of 70 
minutes is here is rather expected, as are delays of several hours, and 
even cancellations.   Long-distance trains in the USA are almost entirely 
for freight. The lack of population density (large cities are far from each 
other) make train passenger travel largely uneconomic and impractical. 
 Long Distance passenger rail service in the US has always lost money. 
 That's why is was such a pleasant surprise for us to discover that in 
Germany train travel between the large cities - which are much closer 
together in Germany than the US - is actually a reasonable and pleasant way 
to travel.

Sometimes I think it is not easy for Europeans to imagine the disadvantages 
of geographic size. Let me offer two  quick examples:  (1) My state, 
Illinois, is about in the middle of US by both location and by state size. 
Illinois is more than twice the size of Bavaria. (2) Were I to travel from 
Chicago to Los Angeles by train (something I would anticipate as an ordeal) 
it would take at least two days - and that's only if there were no delays. 
 It would also cost far more than flying.

comments.text:
+37683769 In October 2013 my wife and I took out first train trip in 
Germany -- Berlin to Braunschweig, I think.  Not long before our train was 
to arrive a solemn voice announced over the loudspeaker something like, 
,,Wir müssen unsere Entschuldigen anbieten, es gibt eine Verspatung von 
fünf Minuten".   To the bewilderment of the Germans, my wife and I burst 
out laughing.  You see, in our part of the USA a passenger train being five 
minutes behind schedule would be considered pleasantly and unusually 
punctual.  Where we live, an announcement of such a "delay" would be 
thought a wry joke.  

We took many other trips on Deutsche Bahn and found the trains uniformly 
clean, pleasant, quiet, comfortable and above all, on time.    There are 
many wonderful and unexpected things in Germany.  The excellent passenger 
rail service is certainly among them.

Your teachers were mistaken: as an adverb or an adjective, "further" and 
"farther" have always been interchangeable when talking about physical 
distance. In a metaphorical sense, "further" is actually the correct form 
(which is why we say "futhermore" and not "farthermore"). This is they same 
on both sides of the Atlantic, but many style guides and teachers 
incorrectly insist this is wrong.

Bahn train personnel stay overnight when they are working long distance

Schönes Thema, gefällt mir.

Da außer dem Interconnex im Moment keine Privatbahn Fernverkehr anbietet, 
könnte man sogar sagen, alles was nicht weiß ist, fährt Nahverkehr 
(Produktkategorie C). Außländische (TGV, Wagenmaterial der Eurociites) 
sowie Nachtzüge natürlich ausgeklammert.

Das bei so einem Thema immer die leidige Pünklichkeitsdiskussion aufkommt 
ist allerdings beschämend für uns Deutsche. Wobei mein Eindruck ist, das 
sich meistens die Gelegenheitsfahrgäste am lautesten beschweren, oder die, 
die nicht selber ihre Karte gezahlt haben, sondern z.B auf Firmenkosten 
fahren (mussten), und sonst "verwöhnte" Autofahrer sind, während die echten 
Stammkunden i.d.R wissen, wie man seine Zugreise so plant, das man Puffer 
drin hat und Anschlüsse kriegt. Alles was weniger als 5 Minuten 
Umsteigezeit ist, ist ja selbst für die Bahn kein (geplanter) Anschluss. 
Dann muss man bloß noch die Übersetzung der Verspätungsdurchsagen kennen 
("wenige Minuten = 1-5 min, "5 Minuten" = 5-10, und so in 5er Schritten 
weiter) und schon bringt einen nix mehr auf die Palme. Aber ich fürchte, 
der quengelsüchtige Deutsche wird das erst kapieren, wenn unser Nahverkehr 
mal so an die Wand gefahren wurde, wie das in Großbrittanien passiert istl, 
wo man ja nun mühvoll versucht, die Folgen der Privatisierung halbwegs 
auszubügeln (Brittischer Zugverkehr als Kontrast zum diesen Film wäre doch 
eigentlich auch mal ein interessantes Video-Thema *anstups* ;-) )

Nicht ganz zustimmen möchte ich der Aussage RBs seien geerell unbequem, zum 
einen, weil auf etlichen RBs nach Ausschreibungen Neufahrzeuge zum Einsatz 
(z.B 440er, 425 erkommen uvm), und die im Video zu sehenden n-Wagen immer 
mehr verdrängen, zum andern, weil die n-Wagen an sich keine unbequmenen 
Wagen sind: Öffenbare Fenster, seitliche Kopfstützen (besonders wenn man 
drin schlafen will), Toilleten in jeden Wagen, i.d.R Durchgängige 4er

Stammfahrgäste könnens (meistens) ...

captions.text:
During the World Cup, The Onion
had an article about how it was hoped

that the spectacle would
raise the spirits of Germans
as they struggled to cope with terrible adversity:
Unemployment at a massive five per cent!
Average life expectancy only eighty years!

And they're still waiting for a high-speed
rail link from Hanau to Gelnhausen!

The Onion is a satirical website,
so it probably doesn't matter, but...
...did you notice the terrible mistake?
Yes of course!

There already is a high-speed rail link
between Hanau and Gelnhausen.

However, it is true that high-speed trains
don't stop at Gelnhausen.

This is because Gelnhausen
is very close to Hanau;

and, although a nice place to visit,
isn't big enough or important enough
for high-speed trains to stop there.

So you have to take a high-speed train
to either Hanau or Fulda,
and then a local train from there.
Trains go pretty much everywhere in Germany,

and most of them are operated by
the state-owned company Deutsche Bahn.

There are different types of train
for different types of journey,
and it can be a little bit confusing.
So here is my helpful, simple little guide.

Deutsche Bahn services can be divided
into two main categories.

"Fernbahn" means long-distance trains,
which are normally white.

"Nahverkehr" means local trains,
and they're normally red.
Other operators don't follow this convention,

but since most trains in Germany
are operated by Deutsche Bahn,
it's a pretty good rule of thumb.
In many parts of Germany,

the local trains are fully integrated
with the local public transportation system,

which is cool, because it means I can even
use them with my bus ticket.

In many German cities and urban areas
there's a sytem called the "S-Bahn".
This is a mass transit commuter rail system

connecting the city centre with the suburbs
and the surrounding towns.

You can get an S-Bahn train
wherever you see this sign,

and in the city centre it sometimes
acts as a kind of a metro system.
Next is the RegionalBahn.

These are slow trains
that connect small towns and villages.

They're not very comfortable, but that doesn't
matter because they don't travel long distances.
RegionalExpress trains are slightly faster,

go slightly further, and don't stop
at every single station on route.

So they provide pretty good connections
between towns and cities.

In some parts of Germany
there are InterRegio-Express trains,

which are like RegionalExpress
except that they cover longer distances.

Germany's long-distance trains
can be a little bit expensive,

but you can get some very good deals
if you buy your ticket in advance.

I'd also recommend reserving seats,
because they can get quite full.

Deutsche Bahn's flagship, of course,
is the Intercity-Express,

the high-speed trains which, on some stretches,
can go as fast as 300 kilometers an hour:
that's more than 180 miles an hour.
You can get from Hamburg to Munich in six hours.

And where the ICE doesn't go, there's still the
plain old Intercity, which is still quite fast.

And if you're travelling very long distances,
the Eurocity is the same as the Intercity
except that it crosses international boundaries,

and it may have cars
from other countries' national carriers.
So it really is that simple.

Take a white train to get
from one end of the country to the other,

and a red train to get
from one village to the next.
If you have something for my notice board,
please send it to this address.

Please note that I can only accept
letters and postcards,
so please don't send me parcels or packages,
or anything that must be signed for.
